titleStmt.title: Three Daughters Harran
SHAWI Corpus
titleStmt.funder: Funded by the FWF Austrian Science Fund under the number P 33574

publicationStmt.distributor: Austrian Center for Digital Humanities and Cultural Heritage

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.
Private URIs using the rend prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a rendition element in VICAV rendition library.
Private URIs using the assets prefix are pointers to the location of the SHAWI media assets.

spanGrp.span: Once there was a rich man in town, owner of money, one who is rich and has prestige; a well-known man, a man (whose words are) heard.
He had three daughters and said to himself, “I want to see how wise my daughters are, I mean how smart they are.”
He wanted to measure their wisdom and said, “My daughters, come here!” He called the three of them and they sat down next to him.
He said, “My daughters, how much do you love me?” So he asked his daughters, “How much do you like me?” In this way their father was talking to them.
The oldest one said, “My father, I love you as big as the world; as big as the world I love you,” she said to her father.
The middle one said to her father, “My father, I love you as big as the world, as much as gold and money this world has, as much as everything. I love you more than anything!”
He said, “Well!” Then he asked the youngest one saying, “My daughter, how much do you love me?”
She said, “My father, I love you as much as salt!”
“O dear God,” he said, “Is she a fool? Is she insane? The other two love me as big as the world, as much as gold;
and this little one, whom I thought would be the smartest, loves me as much as salt?!”
He said, “My daughter, come here, let me see what you mean by saying that you love me as much as salt.”
She said, “My father, everytime when I roll a kebab, when I make food, I put salt on it;
everytime when I put salt on it and when I eat it, I remember you. So much I love you. I love you as much as salt.
That means you are always in my mind. You never go out of my mind. I always love you like the salt on food.”
